title: Telling someone that his build sucks =/= being constructive
body:
Went essence reaver on ashe, seemed good to me, i liked it but the inevitable comment came :

«Oh your build sucks»
And then, «I'm not being rude, i'm being constructive»

Right, telling someone that his build sucks is indeed very constructive.
At least have some arguments.

replies.body:
What I personally do, so in the case of Ashe: "Hm, Ashe, why do you have Essence Reaver?"

When asked instead of told, you are bring up conversation and instead of seeming like you are coming off with a better-than-thou like attitude. 

You here their reason, and then build off what they said and make suggestions, that way, you are speaking to them as an equal instead of treating them inferior.

Meh, even that response seems to be judgmental. It implies that Essence Reaver is a bad option on Ashe right off the start, which telling them that their build sucks does as well. You are basically doing the same thing, except trying to be nice about it lol. Instead, you should probably just tell them that X item isn't typically the best build on X champ for X reason.

If I'm a new player and you ask me that question, I'm going to be like, "Well, seems like an obvious choice. I get great AD, CD, lifesteal, and a passive that allows me to perma Q."

Well with newer players it is easier, they are likely to believe anything because they are new.

You are missing my point here. You are not being nice, since it is still implying the person shouldn't be doing it. It's kind of a belittling question. Lol, there is a difference in trying to be nice, and being nice. Need to give some insight as to why you think something, not just saying you are wrong lol, especially with the given case about Ashe building an item that is seems decent for what she does.

I think they're just the type of guy who doesn't like being told something opposite to what they think if they pick up on an implication like that and getting angry instead of answering the question.

There is a huge difference in implications when you ask instead of tell. Yeah, there's still going to be a slight implication that you're belittiling the other guy but no one is really going to pick up on that unless they're that insecure or looking for that kind of response (Like what I used to do when I pick up 4 Dorans as Rengar and people ask me why I have them. I was expecting the question and relished being aloof and sort of toxic about it by saying "It's my build, I build what I want". Not anymore ofc).

By asking you're actively showing that you want a discussion and not a one-way blame game.

Barring some niche tankbuster cases like Malzahar, you NEED an ADC to take out bruisers effectively, whereas if you have no burst AP all it means is you have to be a little more careful around their squishies.

I guess the idea is that Locket has more tank stats and a shield active. Banner's still better for immortal minions, though.

I agree with your post.

However essence reaver does suck on ashe.

Ashe already has low damage. So you need to ramp up damage items as fast as possible to be as big of a threat as other ad's. Also mid to late game you rarely run out of mana unless you skirmish alot but ashe is more of a team fighter because of her ult so I would say that pretty much every stage of the game essence reaver is trumped by pretty much everything else a ad might buy.

Am I doing it right?

That depends largely on your playstyle. I actually think Essence Reaver was made specifically for Ashe.

She doesn't need mana early, but her Volley cooldown scales so hard, that she can really use the mana at the time you complete the Reaver.

Of course her passive makes starting IE probably the best choice, but as second or third item I would take ER over any other lifesteal item.

but if you forgo a atk speed item as a 2nd item you are cutting into your mid game. If you take it as a 3rd item you are losing armor pen which is needed to deal with tanks at this point. If you take it as a 5th item you are losing out on more life steal or better passives or better damage. If you take it as a 6th item you lose out on your one survivability item.

See what I am saying? At every point in the game it cuts ashe's damage or survivability compared to other items in the game. This is a problem with reaver and not so much ashe.

I usually see penetration as 4th or 5th item. if you have no base damage, simply getting more AD gives more than penetration could amplify.

For AS, Berserkers and Zeal should be enough early, besides, on Ashe that first guarenteed crit is important, so getting more AD helps there too.

Also it doesnt necessarily cut your damage, it shifts some damage from your AA to your Volley, but that also gives you more lifesteal and more survivability, because of AoE slow.

If a tank or bruiser has randuins omen and you only have raw ad their is a good chance that tank or bruiser will be able to soak all the damage you throw at them. Also LW is very cost efficient for its cost and stats it also is very effective against low and high armor targets making it a very valuable buy as a 3rd item especially because tanks will be finishing items right around then too.

True, but Essence Raver is going to give the Ashe the ability to have her Q always on, so even if it takes longer to kill the tank, they don't actually get to do anything to her because she can kite them all day.

However ashe doesn't particularly have mana problems. Out of all 4 of her skills 3 require mana. Out of those 3 both frost shot and enchanted crystal arrow will exclusively be used in team fights or a skirmish.. Volley has a very small cost for what it does. It only cost 60 mana and easily is spammable. Frist shot is easily the biggest mana sink at 8 mana per attack then enchanted crystal arrow at 100 mana. However ashe's mana pool is quite large at most points in the game. Scaling up to 827 at lvl 18 with no items. So assuming you have 0 mana regen and have 1.5 atks per second and a team fight last 10 seconds. 100 mana for ult. 2 volleys at 120 mana and 15 attacks for 120 mana for frost shot. you only would use roughly 340 mana In a ideal case for a 10 second fight. The reality is you will use less mana for the same period of time. So you have over half your mana pool left for any post team fight skirmish. Or alternatively you could go into a team fight at half mana and easily have your passive for 10 seconds. If you are buying Reaver for the mana passive ashe doesn't particularly need it. If you are buying it for damage or life steal their are better options.

Source: http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Ashe
It's time sensitive team based video game... and your teammates don't have time to instruct you as to why you wasted 3200 gold on a sub optimal item.

Except for natural experimentation perhaps?

Optimally is questionable anway.

Everyone firmly beliefed Runaan is total trash untill the Koreans startet experimenting on Kayle.

But yet, it was highly ranked Koreans experimenting on it, not low elo NA players. So honestly, unless your Diamond 1+, and truly understand how this game works, stick to the "optimal" guides found on Lolking, etc. There is a reason it's optimal, and that's because someone(highly ranked, not low elo) tried it out and found the most success with it.
Give you a little secret: I build Runaan on Kayle long before the Koreans did and I was getting a lot of flag for it until then. Afterwards everyone was like "you build her with Runaan, right?"

There are also people that don't know how to actually build certain champions but will tell you that you have a bad build. My first time playing Rek'Sai, I did what I usually do. Analyze the champs stats and abilities and think "hmn, what items would work well with this champ" so I built um... trying to remember. It ended up being mostly a high ranked build for her besides 2 items that I swapped out because I added like an attack speed item to her or something. And then this person on the team kept telling me I wasn't building enough attack speed on her and kept telling me I was bad. I didn't have time to go check builds for her so I was like "I mean, she has attack speed as her passive on her ult so I think I probably have a decent amount, but alright I'll add some more". 
And I actually did well in the match, but of course this person (who eventually told us he was a little kid and laughed because he was "doing better than us old people") kept trash talking me and my friends all game and using hate speech and whatnot (I like to think he got banned in the end) and upon looking at all the high-ranking builds for Rek I discovered that like hardly any of the "high ranking builds" for her have a lot of attack speed items, and I actually had built 4/6 items for one of the top rated builds for her. 

So sometimes someone telling you that your build sucks doesn't mean anything. A lot of times they may just flat out not actually know how that champ works.

Yeah, a lot of people are afraid of trying new things. Which can cost them the game if they build the same 6 items per game. I prefer building for the situation over any inflexible guide. Then again, I don't play much in ranked so there's a lot less pressure from teammates to build "correctly".

Then there's always the case of trying to give constructive criticism, like "oh hey adc you might want to build bork because of the health stacking they have." "F*ck off, don't tell me how to play the game." 

Some people are just douches, and will have a negative comment no matter how you approach it.

I will never be able to properly process how people let other strangers behind a computer screen have such an impact on them. 

This literally blows my mind.
